Come, thou soother of my cares,</br>Taper, snow-white tube of clay,</br>Let me fill thee to the top</br>Sweet thy taste at break of day.
See yon bench beneath the tree,</br>There I will thy sweets enjoy,</br>From my pocket snatch a book;</br>Books wth thee can never cloy:
Spenser, Dryden please me much,</br>Shakespear, Milton, better still,</br>But without thee cannot please,</br>Say or write whate'er they will.
Let the civit-cat supply</br>Beaus and belles with their perfume,</br>I'd no musk, indeed not I,</br>Thou art sweeter, I presume.
Bacchus, God of joyous wine,</br>Half his empire owes to thee;</br>'Tis from thy inspiring breath</br>Converse flows and social glee.
Hodge, returning from the barn,</br>Tir'd with labour, homeward goes,</br>Thro' short pipe he draws new strength,</br>Chears his heart, and warms his nose.
"Send me store of Indian weed,"</br>Hear, O Jove, this one request,</br>Let me but this good enjoy,</br>Kings and princes take the rest.</br>
